title.narrative: Supporting preparedness, mitigation and response to COVID-19 on the most vulnerable populations in Syria

description.narrative:
COVID-19 is exacerbating the already dire humanitarian situation in Syria, particularly for the most vulnerable, already suffering from multiple-impacts of 9 years conflict, leaving the most vulnerable (women, children, elderly, persons with disabilities) without access to healthcare, food, safe water, sanitation and stretching the already limited infrastructure. The rapid spread of COVID-19, coupled with a public health system that is fractured from years of conflict, creates additional challenges for the operational response. Maintaining access to hygiene is crucial to support a healthy immune system and reduce the spread of the COVID-19 virus.
Taking into consideration the UNOCHA 2020 COVID-19 Reserve Allocation and the needs identified in the field, AAH will focus on preventing the spread of COVID-19 by providing life-saving assistance: hygiene kits and awareness posters teaching communities prevention, early detection and control of COVID-19. The project will address the immediate needs of vulnerable and crisis-affected populations in Aleppo governorate by distributing 4,500 hygiene kits to 22,500 individuals. The content of the hygiene kits is in line with the WASH cluster’s specifications. The following communities of two sub-districts (Menbij and Jebel Saman) in Aleppo governorate will be targeted, based on initial Rapid Needs Assessments and stakeholder input: Shahda, Wadihah Al-Jadidah, Sukkariyeh, Kharayej Deham, Khan Al-Asal, Salheen, and As-Sukkari.
The dissemination and hanging of awareness posters in public places will be conducted by SARC, and the distribution of hygiene kits will be done by the local NGO DARB Association, which has access in the target communities. Action Against Hunger received the approval from the Ministry of Social Affairs and Labor and from SARC to work with the local NGO. After the necessary due diligence, AAH signed an MOU with DARB Association. The proposed project mainstreams and incorporates protection principles and promotes meaningful access, safety and dignity. AAH is capitalizing on lessons learnt and best practices from previous interventions and considers Sphere Standards, relevant Clusters’ guidance and WHO’s recommendations on COVID 19. Particular attention has been paid to ensure activities implemented by AAH are not duplicating activities undertaken by other aid agencies in the area but complement activities in the field.
